Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the assertion that left-wing activists are planning false flag violence disguised as Trump supporters. The only evidence provided is a screenshot of a supposed "Antifa flyer" that has been circulating since 2017.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the "Antifa flyer" is genuine and represents the intentions of left-wing activists. However, it fails to acknowledge that the flyer has been debunked as a fabricated planning document in the past.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation for the "Antifa flyer" which suggests that it was shared as a joke or satire, as indicated by the user who originally posted it on a page called "Hickman County Antifa."
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the "Antifa flyer" has been circulating since 2017 and has been debunked as a fabricated planning document by fact-checking organizations.
Understate: The claim understates the lack of credibility and reliability of the "Antifa flyer" as evidence, as it has been widely discredited and does not hold up under scrutiny.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance and relevance of the "Antifa flyer" by presenting it as proof of a widespread plan by left-wing activists to commit false flag violence disguised as Trump supporters.
